questions.question: Which of the following is a component of the fungal cell wall?
Which of the following is a yeast?
questions.explanation: Cryptococcus is a yeast.Fungal cellOMARROWMannoproteinsB-glucanChitinCell membrane458Option A: Candida is a yeast-like fungus.Option C: Fusarium is a mold/filamentous fungus.Option D: Talaromyces is a dimorphic fungus.

questions.question: Which among the following is not a sexual spore?
questions.explanation: Sporangiospore is not a sexual spore. It is an asexual spore.Fungi can be classified into 4 classes based on sexual spore formation:Fungi imperfecti (Deuteromycetes): These are the fungi whose sexual phases are yet to beidentified. Most of the fungi of medical importance belong to this group.Note: The earlier classification of Phycomycetes, under which Zygomycetes, Oomycetes, and othersub-phyla were present, is now obsolete. Phylum Glomerulomycota has replaced it.ClassAsexual sporeSexual sporeGlomerulomycetesOospores, ZygospoSporangiosporesresAscomycetesAscosporesConidiaBasidiomycetesBasidiosporesConidiaFungi imperfecti (Deuteromy Yet to be identifiedConidiacetes)

questions.question: Which of the following fungal spores are formed by condensation of the hyphal elements?
questions.explanation: Arthrospores are asexual spores that are formed along the mycelium/hyphae by segmentation andcondensation of hyphae.Arthrospores are commonly formed by dermatophytes, especially those belonging to the genusTrichophyton. They are also formed by dimorphic fungi like Coccidiodes sp.459

questions.question: A young patient presents to the dermatology OPD with a history of itchy hypopigmentedpatches over her chest for 6 months. A KOH mount is prepared with the skin scrapingsample, which on microscopy reveals a characteristic appearance as shown in the image.What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical picture and the KOH mount preparation showing the spaghetti and meatballappearance suggest pityriasis versicolor.Pityriasis versicolor is a chronic superficial infection of the stratum corneum caused by Malasseziaglobosa and Malassezia furfur. The most common site involves the neck, chest, back, and upperarms. The lesions often appear as hypopigmented areas.The KOH mount reveals fungal hyphae that are short and thick (like spaghetti or banana) andmany variously sized spores (like meatballs or grapes) referred to as spaghetti and meatballs orbananas and grapes appearance.Treatment includes topical azoles or terbinafine for 2 weeks.The image below shows the hypopigmented lesions of P. versicolour over the chest.460Electron microscopic image of Malassezia furfur3/16/2015HVmagWDmode10 pm5:25:53 PM 20.00 kV 10 000 x 10.3 mm SE

questions.question: Which of the following statements about dermatophytes is true?
questions.explanation: Microsporum infects only skin and hair, not nails.Dermatophytes include 3 genera:Microsporum: It infects only hair and skin (not nails). The species included in this genus are-• M. gypseum• M. canis•M. nanum.• Epidermophyton: It infects only skin and nails (not hair). E. floccosum is the only species in thisgenus.•⚫ Trichophyton: It infects skin, hair, and nails. The species falling under this genus are-.• T. rubrum• T. mentagrophytes• T. tonsurans• T. schoenleinii• T. violaceum

questions.question: 448A 23-year-old-lady came to the dermatology clinic with complaints of hair loss and thepresence of firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft as shown. Thereis no associated pruritis of the scalp. Which of the following could be the most probablecausative agent?
questions.explanation: 461The presence firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft is suggestiveof black piedra. The causative agent of this condition is Piedraia hortae.Piedra is a superficial fungal infection of the hair shaft. It is of two types:• Black piedra: It is characterized by firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hairshaft. Scalp hair is most often affected. Hair becomes brittle and breaks easily leading tocomplains of hair loss. It is caused by Piedraia hortae.• White piedra: It is characterized by soft, white or light brown transparent nodules that are easilydetached from the hair. It affects pubic, axillary, facial hair more commonly than scalp hair. Itis caused by Trichosporon beigelii.Management involves shaving or cutting off the affected hair along with topical antifungals.

questions.question: A 45-year-old diabetic patient presented with complaints of discoloration of his toenail for thepast 4 months as shown in the image below. Which pathogen most commonly causes thiscondition?449
questions.explanation: Black piedraWhite piedra462The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of onychomycosis and the pathogen mostcommonly causing this condition is Trichophyton rubrum. Diabetes increases the risk ofonychomycosis.Onychomycosis refers to nail infections caused by fungi. It can be due to dermatophytes,non-dermatophytic moulds, and candida. Tinea unguium refers to nail infections caused bydermatophytes. This condition may affect toenails or fingernails, but toenail infections areparticularly common.The following photomicrograph of the nail segment in KOH shows T. rubrum fungal hyphaeinvading nail cells.The following image is of a lactophenol cotton blue(LPCB) mount showing pyriform shapedmicroconidia on the hyphae of T. rubrum.463

questions.question: Which of the following organisms causes disease following traumatic inoculation into theskin?
questions.explanation: Sporothrix schenckii causes infection followed by traumatic inoculation into the skin.It is a dimorphic fungus that lives on vegetation such as grasses, trees, rose bushes, etc. Followingtraumatic inoculation into the skin as in thorn prick, S schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronicgranulomatous infection. This is usually further followed by spread along the draining lymphaticsand lymph nodes as shown in the image below.BACSporotrichosisLinear nodules along the lymphaticsSubcutaneous mycoses are usually caused by traumatic inoculation of the causative fungus. Theseinclude:Subcutaneous mycCausative agent/sosesSporotrichosisSporothrix schenckii464Subcutaneous mycosesChromoblastomycosisCausative agent/sPhialophora verrucosaFonsecaea pedrosoiFonsecaea compactaRhinocladiella aquaspersaCladophialophora carrioniiPhaeohyphomycosi Exophiala jeanselmeiPhialopShora richardsiaeBipolaris spiciferaWangiella dermatitidisMycetomaPseudallescheria boydii (Anamorph Scedosporium apiospermum).Madurella mycetomatis Madurella griseaE jeanselmeiAcremonium falciforme

questions.question: Which of the following is false about the most commonly used culture media for growingfungi?
questions.explanation: Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA) is the most commonly used culture media for growing fungi. Itdoes not contain taurocholate.It consists of antibiotics like gentamicin or chloramphenicol to inhibit the contaminant bacteriaand also cycloheximide to inhibit the growth of saprophytic fungi. It has an acidic pH of 5.4.Media used in mycology can be classified as:•Specific media-• SDA agar•Czapek-Dox medium• Birdseed agar•Cornmeal agar• Non-specific media-• Blood agar• Brain heart infusion agar465Trichophyton rubrum on SDACandida albicans on SDASporothrix schenckii On SDA

questions.question: A gardener from the sub-Himalayan region presented with multiple ulcerative eruptionsalong the lymphatics of his hand. A tissue biopsy was taken and sent for culture. Microscopicexamination of the organism cultured is shown in the image. Identify the organism.
questions.explanation: The presence of multiple ulcerative eruptions along the lymphatics in a gardener from thesub-Himalayan region and the microscopic finding of flower-like clusters of conidia are suggestiveof sporotrichosis, caused by Sporothrix schenckii. It is a thermally dimorphic fungus that lives onvegetation.The lesions occur following traumatic inoculation of the fungus. A granulomatous nodule is firstformed at the site of inoculation that may progress to form a necrotic or ulcerative lesion. Theinfection can spread via lymphatic channels from the skin and subcutaneous tissue to the lymphnodes resulting in formation of secondary ulcers on the lymph nodes. This condition is known aslymphocutaneous sporotrichosis. This disease is commonly encountered among gardeners, forestworkers and manual labourers.Clinical presentation of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis:466

questions.question: A farmer developed multiple ulcerative nodules along the lymphatics following a rose thornprick a week ago. Microscopic finding of the skin biopsy is given below. What is the likelydiagnosis?451
questions.explanation: The image shows an asteroid body which is characteristically seen in a case of sporotrichosis.Asteroid bodies are formed due to the deposition of the immune complexes around the yeast cell.It consists of a central rounded or oval basophilic, cigar-shaped yeast cell surrounded peripherallyby eosinophilic radiations. Formation of such structures is called the Splendore-Hoeppliphenomenon.Note: Asteroid bodies are also seen in sarcoidosis. Those are irregular, star-shaped inclusions seenin multinucleate giant cells.

questions.question: A farmer from the sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury a year back and developed awarty, verrucous growth at the site of prick. A skin biopsy sample was taken and sent forhistopathological examination. The characteristic microscopic body as shown in the imagewas seen. Which of the following could be the most likely diagnosis?452
questions.explanation: The history of a slowly spreading warty, verrucous lesion following a thorn prick injury and thehistopathological image showing medlar bodies is suggestive of chromoblastomycosis.Chromoblastomycosis (chromomycosis) is a subcutaneous mycotic infection that is usually causedby traumatic inoculation. Over months to years, the primary lesion becomes verrucous andwart-like with extension along the draining lymphatics.Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous and the dark sclerotic bodies may be seen withinleukocytes or giant cells called medlar/copper penny bodies.Subcutaneous mycCausative agent/sosesSporotrichosisChromoblastomycosisPhaeohyphomycosiSMycetomaSporothrix schenckiiPhialophora verrucosa Fonsecaea pedrosoiFonsecaea compactaRhinocladiella aquaspersaCladophialophora carrioniiExophiala jeanselmeiPhialophora richardsiaeBipolaris spiciferaWangiella dermatitidisPseudallescheria boydii (Anamorph Scedosporium apiospermum).Madurella mycetomatis Madurella griseaE jeanselmeiAcremonium falciforme

questions.question: A middle-aged man from south India presented to the OPD with a swelling in his left foot thatis unresponsive to antibiotics. On examination, multiple discharging sinuses were noted. Thedischarge contained brown granules that were soft in consistency. Which of the following islikely the causative agent?
questions.explanation: 467A swelling with multiple discharging sinuses with brown granules that is unresponsive to theantibiotics is suggestive of eumycetoma caused by Madurella mycetomatis.Mycetoma is a chronic, granulomatous infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissues, fascia andbone, which most often affects the foot or the hand. It can be divided into three types-eumycetomas, actinomycetomas and botryomycosis.Infection follows traumatic inoculation of the organism into the subcutaneous tissue from soil orvegetable sources. Within host tissues, the organisms develop to form compacted colonies (grains)0.5-2 mm in diameter, the color of which depends on the organism responsible. It results intumefactions, deformities and draining sinuses discharging these grains or granules.Laboratory Diagnosis:• A. Direct Examination: The presence of grains in pus collected from draining sinuses or inbiopsy material is diagnostic.• B. Culture Samples should also be cultured, at both 25-30°C and 37°C, on brain-heart infusionagar or blood agar for actinomycetes and on Sabouraud agar (without cycloheximide) for fungi.Treatment:The management of eumycetoma is difficult, involving surgical debridement or excision andchemotherapy. Actinomycetoma on the other hand, responds well to rifampicin in combinationwith sulfonamides or cotrimoxazole.Option A: Actinomadura madurae causes actinomycetoma which would respond to antibiotics.Option B: Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis which is characterised by lesions along theroute of lymphatics.Option C: Fonsecaea pedrosoi causes chromoblastomycosis which would not have dischargingsinuses.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a dimorphic fungus?
questions.explanation: Pneumocystis jirovecii is a yeast-like fungus and not a dimorphic fungus.Dimorphic fungi exist in the yeast form in body tissues and cultures maintained at 37°C, and inthe filamentous form in cultures at room temperature(25°C).Examples of dimorphic fungi include:•Blastomyces dermatitidis• Coccidioides immitis• Paracoccidioides brasiliensis• Talaromyces marneffei•⚫ Sporothrix schenckii•Histoplasma capsulatum• Coccidioides posadasii468

questions.question: A 54-year-old man had presented to the clinic with a history of chronic cough. His chest X-rayshowed a mass in the left lung with hilar lymphadenopathy. Biopsy of the mass was done andfindings are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?Gilchrist diseaseb) Darling's diseasec) Desert rheumatismd) Jorge Lobo's diseaseQuestion 17:A 7-year-old boy with a recent history of travel to South America was brought to the hospitalwith fever, enlarged lymph nodes and multiple skin lesions on his face. Tissue sample fromthe lesion shows the following findings under microscopy. Which of the following is the mostlikely causative organism?454
questions.explanation: The given clinical history and the presence of tiny yeast forms within macrophages are suggestiveof Histoplasmosis which is also called Darling's disease. Other names of this condition includeCave's disease and Ohio disease.The causative agent is a dimorphic fungus called Histoplasma capsulatum. Transmissionoccurs via inhalation of conidia.After inhalation, the conidia develop into yeast cells and are engulfed by alveolar macrophages.Within macrophages, the yeasts may disseminate to reticuloendothelial tissues, such as the liver,spleen, bone marrow, and lymph nodes.Biopsy reveals tiny (2-4 microns) oval-shaped yeast cells inside macrophages.On culture and microscopy, tuberculate macroconidia and hyaline septate mold with microconidiaare seen.It is treated using azole antifungals.

questions.question: A 50-year-old male presents with low-grade fever and a skin lesion as shown below. He had ahistory of recent travel to North America. Chest X-Ray reveals consolidation in the right lungwith hilar lymphadenopathy. Culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar at 37°C shows thick-walled,large (7-20 µ), round yeast cells with a single broad-based bud. What is the most probablediagnosis?455
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with pulmonary and cutaneous involvement along with a history oftravel to North America and the characteristic culture findings suggests the diagnosisof Blastomycosis caused by Blastomyces dermitidis.Blastomycosis is a chronic infection, characterized by the formation of suppurative andgranulomatous lesions, especially, in the lungs and skin.It is most common in North America and so is also called North Amerian Blastomycosis.The causative organism is a thermally dimorphic fungus called Blastomyces dermatitidis. Humansare infected by the inhalation of spores in the soil.•.Blastomycosis can present in three forms:Pulmonary disease:• Presents with cough, sputum production, chest pain, and fever•Hilar lymphadenopathy may be present• Focal or diffuse consolidation, miliary lesions, or abscess formation may occur.• Resembles TB and Histoplasmosis• Cutaneous disease:• Involvement of face and exposed parts of the skin• Skin lesion: ulcerated verrucous granulomas with an advancing border and central scarring. Theborder is filled with microabscesses and has a sharp, sloping edge. (image in stem)470• Disseminated disease:•••Multiple skin lesions are the most common presentationHighly fatalGenitourinary tract (especially prostate) is frequently involved• Bone involvement resembles chronic osteomyelitis.It can be diagnosed based on culture findings. Characterictic findings include the presenceof thick-walled round yeast cell with a single broad-based bud when cultured at 37°C. (figure of 8appearance)Treatment:•• Localised mild/moderate disease - Itraconazole (6 months)• Disseminated/ severe disease - Amphotericin B

questions.question: A middle-aged man residing in a rural area presents with psychosis, ataxia and convulsions.On further inquiry, you find out there is history of similar complaints in the family memberswho recently consumed food prepared with grains as shown in the image. What is thepoisoning is most likely due to?
questions.explanation: The given clinical vignette and the presence of dark coloured ergot growing on the wheat as shownin the image are suggestive of ergotism due to Claviceps purpureaMycotic poisoning is of two types: Mycetism and MycotoxicosisMycetism:The fungus itself causes toxic effects.Examples:•Claviceps Ergot poisoning•Coprinecoprine poisoning• Inocybe → muscarine poisoningMycotoxicosis:Fungal toxins contaminate food and cause toxic effects.Examples:• Aflatoxins: These are a type of mycotoxins produced by Aspergillus species of fungi, such asAspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus.• Fusarium toxins• Citrinin toxin was first isolated from Penicillium citrinum.

questions.question: The below given image shows result of hair perforation test. The organism likely to showbelow given appearance is456
questions.explanation: Image shows surface erosion of shaft caused by Trichophyton mentagrophytes.Hair perforation test:471•⚫ Done to differentiate Trichophyton rubrum from mentagrophytes.• Few strands of human hair are placed in a petridish with 20 ml of distilled water and autoclaved.•Few drops of sterile 10% yeast extract and a few fragments of the test fungus are added to thehair strands.• Incubated at 250C for 2-3 weeks.•Hair is removed and examined microscopically in a lactophenol cotton blue stained wetpreparation.⚫ T.mentagrophytes causes surface erosion of the shaft resulting in wedge shaped appearance ofthe shaft.472
